Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Transformation of Elemental Mercury Dispersed by Flooding During Hurricane Harvey
Award.AbstractNarration:
In August 2017, Hurricane Harvey caused catastrophic flooding in southeastern Texas and dispersed liquid elemental mercury [Hg(0)] from an unknown source to an area east of Houston. Preliminary measurements performed days after the hurricane showed mercury concentrations exceeding 2500 mg/kg in floodplain sediments of the San Jacinto River. Because mercury is a highly toxic element, the hurricane-induced contamination may pose a significant threat to public health. This project aims to elucidate the geochemical controls on the methylation of elemental mercury [Hg(0)] in San Jacinto River sediments. Floodplain and river sediment samples will be collected and analyzed for mercury methylation activity. NSF funds will be used to train graduate and undergraduate students at Rutgers University to carry out field work and laboratory mercury analyses. An examination of the transformations of elemental mercury in San Jacinto River sediments dispersed by Hurricane Harvey is a unique opportunity to investigate the fate of elemental mercury in sediments shortly after release and will provide critical information for the development of accurate contaminant transport models and future remediation efforts.

Recent laboratory experiments have shown that certain anaerobic bacteria can take up dissolved Hg(0) and transform intracellular Hg to methylmercury. However, the occurrence of this microbial process in contaminated sediments has not been investigated, and anaerobic methylation of liquid Hg(0) by microbial communities remains poorly understood. In this project, floodplain and river sediment samples collected along the San Jacinto River will be used to test two hypotheses: 1) Elemental mercury in contaminated sediments is converted to methylmercury under anoxic, water-saturated condition; under oxic conditions, elemental mercury is oxidized, but not methylated; and 2) Elevated mercury concentrations in sediments inhibits mercury methylation due to toxicity effects on the microbial community. Laboratory experiments carried out by the research team and students at Rutgers University will test these hypotheses with the goal of obtaining new insights into the geochemical controls on Hg(0) oxidation and methylation in contaminated sediments. NSF funds will be used to train 2 Ph.D. students and 2 undergraduate students. The students will gain interdisciplinary experiences in geochemistry and microbiology as state-of?the-art disciplines in environmental geosciences. The results of this project will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and presentations at national conferences. By elucidating the geochemical conditions that promote methylmercury production, the investigators aim to better inform local public health officials and environmental managers about the possible dangers associated with this contamination event.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On November 10th 2017, approximately two and a half months after Hurricane Harvey, we collected sediment and water samples from six sites along the San Jacinto River near Channelview, Texas. The sampling sites were near areas previously reported by the New York Times to have liquid elemental mercury droplets in a residential neighborhood. Gaseous elemental mercury [Hg(0)] concentration in the atmosphere was measured at each site. Sediment and water samples were returned to Rutgers University for total mercury and methylmercury analysis.

We found no elemental mercury globules in the sediment samples collected along the San Jacinto River. Our data indicated that Hg(0) contamination was not widely dispersed after Hurricane Harvey. However, because the study area was sparsely sampled, localized Hg(0) contamination was not conclusively ruled out.

Simulation of localized Hg(0) contamination in sediment incubations showed that the indigenous sediment microorganisms are able to convert Hg(0) to methylmercury (MeHg).  Analysis of the microbial communities suggested that anaerobic methanogens in the sediments were involved in mercury methylation

The results of this research provided new insights into the biogeochemical cycling of mercury Hg and the factors influencing the production of neurotoxic methylmercury in the environment. This new knowledge has the potential to decrease human and wildlife exposure to this neurotoxic compound. Our research also directly supported the articles outlined by the United Nations Minamata Convention on Mercury through increasing understanding of the transformation and fate of Hg and Hg compounds.

        This NSF grant provided research opportunities for two students in the Environmental Sciences program (Yuwei Wang and Spencer Roth) and one Bioenvironmental Engineering major (Chioma Ekedede). Ms. Ekedede is a female African American student. The students were trained in field methods, including in situ gaseous mercury analysis at the sampling sites.  The students were also trained to perform chemical and biological analyses in the laboratory.

Our research activities were described in the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Fish and Shellfish Program Newsletter.  https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2018-11/documents/fish-news-oct2018.pdf . An abstract of the research findings was submitted to the Hurricane Harvey Symposium, held on August 23, 2018 at Port Aransas Civic Center, Port Aransas, TX. A manuscript containing all the research data is currently being prepared for submission to a peer-reviewed journal for publication.
